'''Jason Sturgeon''' is an American [[country music]] artist born and raised in [[Petersburg, Indiana]].<ref>Cecil, Brian. "[http://www.jasonsturgeonmusic.com Jason Sturgeon Biography.]" Retrieved July 30, 2012</ref> He has released two albums via Toolpusher Records.<ref>Toolpusher Records. "[http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,3028,GAC_26071_6027247_02,00.html Jason Sturgeon.]" Retrieved December 5, 2011</ref>

==Biography==
Sturgeon grew up in a family of [[coal miners]], oilmen and [[farmers]].<ref>Starkey, Larri JO. "[http://www.aqha.com/Showing/World-Show/Blog/111211-Jason-Sturgeon-concert.aspx Country Music and Quarter Horse.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620231502/http://aqha.com/Showing/World-Show/Blog/111211-Jason-Sturgeon-concert.aspx |date=June 20, 2012 }}" Retrieved November 12, 2011</ref> His creative side helped to balance out his love for the outdoors.

Along with music, he enjoyed jockeying, as his grandparents on his mothers’ side had [[thoroughbreds]].<ref>Fox, Kari. "[http://www.thelantern.com/a-e/country-singer-jason-sturgeon-to-horse-around-ohio-expo-center-1.2663395#.UBll6kSTkyC Country Singer Jason Sturgeon to horse around Ohio Expo Center.]" Retrieved Oct 23, 2011</ref> He eventually started racing in AQHA open horse shows and placed 8th in the World Championship Show in Oklahoma City and 4th in the Quarter Horse Congress in [[Columbus, Ohio]].  From 15 until 19 during the summers, he worked in the [[oilfields]] for his family and learned to build, renovate, and basically do anything that needed to be done around the [[farm]].<ref>Hensel, Amanda. "[http://tasteofcountry.com/jason-sturgeon-the-cover/ Jason Sturgeon, 'The Cover'] - Song Review." Retrieved July 13, 2011</ref>

After high school Jason planned to head to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] but his father convinced him to attend college at [[Vincennes University]] first and learn a trade, just in case.<ref>Hoffard, Vince Illionoisan. "[http://thesouthern.com/entertainment/music/sturgeon-doesn-t-regret-choosing-music/article_06228c2e-63f9-11e1-bb81-0019bb2963f4.html Sturgeon doesn't regret choosing music.]" Retrieved 2011</ref> He earned his degrees and became a medical device engineer for [[Cook Medical]] in [[Bloomington, Indiana]].

After graduating from Vincennes University, he moved to Nashville to pursue his music career. Soon after moving to Nashville, he began touring, spending the majority of his first two years touring. His rapid city-to-city lifestyle inspired one of his hits "Time Bomb," a song about always being at a different venue in a different state. While he loved being on the road, he realized that he needed to settle down. He had plenty of experiences to write about after his time on the road. In 2012, Sturgeon played over 200 shows, and in 2013, he's on pace to top even that. In his 200+ shows during 2012, he opened for the likes of [[Gary Allan]], [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Rodney Atkins]], [[Luke Bryan]], and [[Dierks Bentley]], among others.

==Music career==
The band opened for artists like [[Brooks & Dunn]], [[Rodney Atkins]], [[Luke Bryan]]<ref>The Sentinel. "[http://cumberlink.com/entertainment/arts-and-theatre/jason-sturgeon-to-play-gm-nationals-today/article_961ff9a0-bce7-11e1-bed9-0019bb2963f4.html Jason Sturgeon to play GM Nationals today.]" Retrieved Jun 23, 2012</ref> and others who were coming through the area, and they even released their own CD in 2008. Tapped to be part of [[Kenny Chesney]]’s “Next Big Star” competition,<ref>Doerschuk, Bob. "[http://www.roughstock.com/blog/new-artist-spotlight-jason-sturgeon/ New Artist Spotlight: Jason Sturgeon.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123124022/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/new-artist-spotlight-jason-sturgeon |date=November 23, 2010 }}" Retrieved Nov 16, 2010</ref> Sturgeon continued as a solo act. He traveled to Nashville but returned to Indiana until he received a phone call from [[Dane Clark]], a member of [[John Mellencamp]]’s band.

He released ''That's Me'' in 2010.<ref>Staff, Roughstock. "[http://www.roughstock.com/audio/jason-sturgeon-that-s-me/ Jason Sturgeon - That's Me.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404063122/http://www.roughstock.com/audio/jason-sturgeon-that-s-me |date=April 4, 2011 }}" Retrieved March 14, 2011</ref> ''Cornfields & Coal'' followed in September 2013.
